text:
style="opacity:0" is exactly the same as style="opacity:1" in the <rect> 
element.

By changing the "0" to "0.01" (in broken.svg) I achieve the effect I am looking 
for. I've included both a broken and working SVG file. Both appear the same in 
the Adobe SVG plugin to IE5 (looks approximately like BRRS009251.jpg) but yield 
different results when sent through the SVG rasterizer.

creator: deweese@apache.org
text:
This appears to be a bug in Apple's implementation of the Java2D API.
We continue to work with them to sort out the problems here.

I looked into this.
The problem is that we use composite==null to represent opacity of 0.0.
In AbstractGraphicsNode::paint it currently checks if composite is null and if
so it doesn't set the composite in the Graphics2D.  It should return if
composite is null (opacity is zero so nothing will show).

However it appears that the bridge does not always set the composite to 
SrcOver when it should.  The SVG element for example doesn't handle any
of the presentation attributes in it's buildGraphicsNode method.
The Image Bridge also fails to set the composite on the 'sub' node it creates.

I've attached a patch that is a start down fixing this problem, but I
suspect that there are more cases like Image, which are hard to track down.
So I have not commited the current patch (basically I'm in over my head
so I'll let Thierry sort out the rest of the details :).

text:
Now fixed.  Bridge constructs AlphaComposite with alpha of 0.
AbstractGraphicsNode::paint now returns if the composite alpha
is less than 0.001 (where a 255 value would go to less than .5
ie couldn't effect output).
